reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis review is directed to the Devs. My friends and I love to play Savage Lands and relize it has some potential. We have some ideas of things we would love to see in upcoming updates. First off walking is a long and tiring proccess in Savage lands, in-game we have a main base camp with a town hall, forge, etc; but when we go hunting for food or going for minerals it is a lengthy proccess and it would be great if you could add mounts. In the way of mounts I was thinking that of course there should be horses, but why not have something more exciting? I don't know about you but I would personaly love to charge into battle atop my burly war bear to take out my enimies, or soar through the skies atop my dragon stead. I'm sure that you have heard this from lots of your players, but the map NEEDS to be larger. There is simply not enough to explore! I understand this game is relatively new, so for where it is this game is doing great. I reccomend this game to anyone willing to grind for materials for little reward other than to have them, and to survive in game. While I cannot say this game is a must-buy it should not be overlooked. So Devs I hope you have not overlooked this review and will take my ideas into consideration, and than you for providing hours of social fun with my friends.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

6/10
Savage Lands shows promise, though in it's current state I'm not sure I can recommend it with such minimal content to anyone except players who want to support the development. I have around 30 ish hours logged in the game; which mainly consisted of exploring the repetitive island (I wanted to like this game!). After around 4 hours though, I had accomplished everything possible. The graphical look of the world is generically pretty though uninspired. I've heard it said that Savage Lands is like Rust meets Skyrim, and if so, it took the most boring parts of both and dropped them on an island together.

-- Update: changed status to recommended due to conversation with developer (see below comments).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I found myself the lone survivor on an empty beach. I strolled the beach looking for supplies, I found a stick, a tool, a frost fern and some clothes. I continued to walk the beach were I found an abandoned fire and shelter, sadly the fire was out. I chooped down a few trees and found plenty of stone, however I had difficulty finding any sticks or flint, therefore I coudn'y build a shelter. I spent so long worrying about starting a fire I gave up and decided to worry more about a shelter. I then realized I was out of food, so I went hunting, where I found nothing to eat/hunt. I suddenly found myself walking into a blizzard. My cold bar went down to 0%, I thought to myself, this is the end. I braced myself, but I was still alive. Suddenly my health bar went down, and down, and down, so I went to my nice warm home and played my new game, Savage Lands.

Savage Lands is amazing, not to mention the fact that it's an earlly acess game, however there are a few improvments I would like to make:
*I think the girls (such as myself) would really apreciate havng a femae character available, maybe more customizable characters too.
*I can't find any sticks, maybe there could be more sticks in the game, or maybe you can break a log and turn it into a stick/sticks.

Aside from that and a little bit of lag, I give this game a 9/10 It's definetly worth the money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My first impressions:

Character feels super fat, like you're constantly running up a hill. Not really any sense of direction when you start out. I just ran around for a while, killed a few skeletons and a wolf, then froze to death. All I really found in this time were four of the same hammer, and some meat. The combat system also feels a little boring. I would like to see some major improvments with the crafting menu as well. I was expecting my computer to handle it better too, it was stuttering a bit.

The game is too early in development for me to really judge it properly. Definitely a lot of potential here. I look forward to trying it again in a few updates.

(I did thumbs up this on purpose. I'm not hating on the game, just sharing my opinions with those who are considering buying the game.)
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been very interested in this game since I first seen it pop up on EA... However, being against EA, I told myself I would wait quite a bit until purchasing.  Now that the game has been out for a bit and seeing tons of great reviews I decided to take the plunge. Very glad that I did.

It constantly gets compared to Minecraft + Skyrim.  I wouldn't exactly say that is the hybrid I would go with, but I can see it.

It is not a digging game or a block builder.  So dont get excited if that's what you love about Minecraft/Terraria.

It isnt an action rpg.  There arent any NPCs. So if that what you like about Skyrim, then tough.

What it is: Awesome.

You are washed up on a beach.  You find a few supplies that must've fallen off of your very tiny boat.

You have 3 bars that you have to manage.  Cold. HP.  Hunger. All easily managable.

You start of with barely any inventory space... Logical because you washed up basically nude.

You have to gather everything you can!  Build a fire to keep warm and cook meat from the various wild life you will have to kill. (Sorry Bambi lovers)  Make a house to stay safe at night (also keeps you warm).  Cutting down trees, and mining are your main resources, but with lots to explore and find washed up on shore or at various camps where others have perished.

There are several types of enemies that require different tactics and better gear to progress" while you try to gather materials and better your gear.

And there is a giant dragon flying about!

This game is constantly getting updated.  The devs are constantly keeping the community in the loop and taking suggestions.  It seems like the devs want to keep this as realistic as possible but set within a fantasy world... I very much approve of this decision.  I really hope they dont end up taking advice from all of the casual complainers who want some modern-esque survival game.

It is totally worth a pick up.  It isnt anywhere near finished but there is tons to do and lots to see.  I definitely think it is the type of game that one would enjoy to see evolve just as much as you would enjoy the game play.

Note: I unfortunately have not given multiplayer a try
date: so I did not mention that in my review.  All I do know is there are 2 modes
recommended: one pvp and one thats pve co-op style."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will admit that I haven't played many survival type games, I've played the more cutesie ones such as Terraria and Starbound, but nothing lik Savage Lands. I normally don't like games with the idea to survive and craft so hardcore in the beginning of the game, and normally not a fan of the first-person view either but that view has grown on me through other games played.

I LOVE this game so far, could be that I play it with 1-2 other people though... All I know is that I enjoy the challenge and getting to explore while having to find your way back to your camp, etc. It's easy in the beginning with a camp built near the water, but after moving it more inland you really need to rely on a compass and different landmarks of sorts.

Very interested in what changes will come about in the future, hoping perhaps the ability to craft a recall potion" of sorts that can bring you back to your set spawn point is a possibility
date: but if not it's not too terribly hard to navigate yourself."

Sadly I've yet to see any furies or giants, I'm guessing i just not far enough from the start area yet. Can't wait to fight some of the named enemies, planning to go looking for a few tonight.

Things I'd like to see
Would be really nice if building a structure would level the terrain floor, would prevent dropped items from rolling outside under the walls and whatnot, not to mention the ground clipping through the floor of the townhalls.

Ammo counter for the bow, yea i know u can put the arrows in the hotbar but after u use those 25 u can't tell how many more u have, not a big thing would just be semi helpful.

Quiver bag, could only hold arrows but would let them stack to 100 intstead of 25 and have a few slots, could be a worn item maybe accessory slot, other accessories could be cloaks to help warm when in armor that isn't so warm. Epic teir item, after kur combat done could include a fireproof cloak made from kurs own hide.

A block mechanic, shields would be nice but if i can block with my sword at least i wouldn't mind so much.

Some type of cave/dungeon in game would be cool but I'm sure thats already been thought of.

All in all the game is amazing so far and i can see myself playing plenty more in the weeks to come, I love that there is an update countdown in the main menu. I'd recommend this game to just about anyone who likes survival games it has just the right mix of grinding for items and fighting for your life that you'd hope for.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite being a fairly blatant mix of skyrim's atmosphere and the popular minecraft survival style sandbox, I'd say this games worth a shot. Calling it what it is or not, the two things really mingle well. I feel this game has potential because of its difficulty, atmosphere, and pvp.

Granted, early access, here are some things that could be improved upon:
Dedicated servers and (Subsequently) raising the servers player cap far beyond 8.
Being able to crouch, not just slow walk.
Smoothing of combat system, its not day z clunky but its still could use polishing.
Optimization of graphics. I dont exactly have a great gaming computer, but for the quality of these graphics it shouldn't be as difficult to run smoothly as it seems.
Im sure a lot of people also feel something is missing with no quests, dungeons, or any other true objectives besides survive and attempt to thrive with. However, I dont think it needs it. This could really be an interesting game if rather than copy/pasting the typical survival game mechanics, features, and far too many craftables, instead it took advantage of its multiplayer and gently encouraging players to make the most of an open world, realistic tribal, or even feudal, survival/ pvp warfare system. Something about this game just makes me yearn for that kind of experience.

Overall, not bad. Gonna stick with it and see how it goes.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is my first review on Steam and I'm going to keep it short.  This game is worth every penny and then some.  I've spent the last 2 years digging through survival games since I outgrew Minecraft.  There are a lot of garbage titles in the genre and that is a good thing as the best games easily rise to the top.  This is one of those gems for sure.  The most amazing thing is that this game isn't even remotely finished and it's already my fav game in the genre by far.  This is intended to become a Skyrim-survivalish game.  So at some point I'm going to be able to cast fireball spells?  Just take my money now.  My only regret is that I bought this game on sale for $8.00, and I really feel bad that the developers are not ♥♥♥♥♥ing the other $12.00 they had planned on.  I've never felt this way about a game and may in fact donate another 12 bucks just so I feel better about it.  Just buy this game... DO NOT watch streams or YouTube videos if you can help it.  The less you know, the more fun you will have.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game I deeply recommend. The game reminds me of Skyrim and dayz in the same game! There are multiple ways to survive and go through your adventure. I love how the environment seamlessly integrates with the gameplay.  Sometimes I feel like I am actually walking on that island.  Although graphics aren't the goal of this game I will say it can really suck your time away from how engaging it is.  However, optimization in the game isn't at an all time high.  So you can expect large lag spikes here and there.  As well as graphical glitches, such as floating deer or flying trees.  The beta of this game is showing a much larger map of amazing proportions and some dungeons with mysteries surrounding them such as why is there a giant meteor or what was the role of the dragon bridge? The beta inculdes dungeons, new bosses, and a better island.  I hope you choose to buy this game and love it as much as I do! :)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe game was fun, and I would reccommend it for those that like Dragons and survival games akin to Don't Starve. However my only complaint is regarding the very limited inventory space as well as limited stacking. Even if the meat is the same you can only have 1 raw meat of that type in a slot. To make a fire you need 3 logs but you can only have 2 per stack. Max inventory space is roughly 11 or 13 slots (can't recall at this time).   Other little annoyence is when you kill an animal it doesn't always give you meat. It would make sense to get a poorer quality of meat instead of none at all. Highly recommend this game to be played with a good friend : )

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A worthwhile Survival with dark fantasy props. A good buy at discount, and even a good bet on full price if you're into the genre.

The game has plenty of  content (mobs, crafts, buildings, ores, trees, etc.) which is good for an EA. The atmosphere is enthralling, making those first hours really challenging when you need to get clothed, fed and find some shelter. At night you'll be on your toes, specially when those snow storms hit.
The challenge then turns into finding bigger game to hunt, and trying not to get outmatched by your potential prey. Experience is much better with friends.

Extra info:
Currently the game's working pretty good. Some crashes, but that's to expect on Beta. Also enjoying the rate of development, makes you feel safer with your bet on a EA.
Had some problem with entering the game when they started the Beta thing, since it wasn't working properly for Linux 64.
It' been working lately though, even though I now need to use lowest graphics. Still runs a bit slow and clunky, but it's enjoyable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played this game when she first popped up on Steam then played it again just under a week ago. Actually I played it with a few friends on both occasions. To say the least, its fun, basic, and gives a decent enough challenge. In addition, after coming back to it, I'm impressed with the progress the dev's are making. Compared to the first time I played it, SL has made massive improvements. It's still a little wonky, hit boxes can be off, the AI will occasionally get confused and you'll see the rarer graphical glitch. However those are the negatives. I'm sure if you scroll through the comments you'll find the more nitpicking detailed issues that people have. However, for a $15 early access indie multiplayer, Savage Lands stands out. It has a comprehensive UI and crafting system, a time consuming yet entertaining grinding system, the graphics and AI are still well built for what it is.

Does it have it's problems? Sure, yet like I said it's an early access indie (that's only $15) and for that I give it a 10/10. Also the Devs are still here! (ikr, rare AF)
Is it worth the money? Absolutely! Especially if you're going to play with friends. You get to set up your own servers, its savable, and it easy AF to set up.
How is SL compared to other Indies/Alphas? It's simple, it doesn't compare. I mean that in a good way. This game hit the nail on the head for me. Nowadays you have to sort through all the glitchy PoS waste of money multiplayers, Indies, and or Alphas that Steam has to offer. All so you can find a remotely decent one to play with friends. Even then, most are pay to win or the Dev's give up on them after the first couple of months, and or the Dev/Devs just run off with the money *cough cough Dean Hall*.

In conclusion, seeing as I'm starting to rant. Overall Savage Lands is still a very solid game and in my opinion it is a load of fun and definitely worth the money.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nEarly development, but game is already fun and challenging. Lack of instructions makes getting started tricky. There are some decent walkthrus on YouTube. When just starting out, be sure to make a hammer and an axe. Hammers can mine rocks and axes can harvest trees and shrubs. Both can be used as weapons. Finding flint can be tricky... seek out boulders that highlight red when you look at them up close. Maneuver during combat... staying behind your enemy is key to avoiding damage. Sneak up on deer from behind.

Early Access Review

This game has a really awesome and unique feel to it, as others have said. it’s bleak, but that just adds to the feel for me, makes you feel very isolated. The whole lore is cool to, and the crafting system seems pretty solid, not to hard to craft stuff, but not hours of grinding hard either.
Basically, it’s visually appealing, not the best graphics ever but the environment is epic. The combat system is okay. As it is a survival game it’s top notch keeping you interested in a deep world. The game seems to be advancing well, with good updates frequently, and a good team running it. This game has some serious potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Savage Lands
Recently exiled from my homeland, I find myself washed up on a beach, in a land filled with chilling cold winds. Nothing in this new place seems familiar.
Maybe - just maybe - I could find shelter from this cold wind.

Nothing seems as I remember, this new land is harsh, cold and savaged. Even the wildlife here seems to be savaged. Last time I went in land, I was chased by a fierce wolf, I barely made it out of there alive. Had it not been for my Frost fern bandage, I would surely have succumbed from the bleeding from the wound the wolf left as a gift on my right leg.
Now all I really want to do is to stay alive, even if it means that I have to find shelter somewhere around the beach.
At least then I can always have a lookout on ships sailing by here. Unfortunately, I have yet to spot any ships coming this way.

The snow storm is still raging outside of my hut, so for now at least - all I can do is sit tight in here. However, I should probably get a plan going, seeing as it seems I will be stuck on this ravaged land for a long time. The cooked wolf meat are soon running out, and I think I spotted a few deer roaming a little further away from the hut. I might go out tomorrow and see if I can at least hunt one of the deer. Now is probably a good time to get some rest so I have a little strength for tomorrows hunting.

Later that night a strange roar is heard
What is that? That certainly did not sound like any sound I heard before. Could it be people using some kind of horn? Nay, I have yet to see anyone around here. Frankly I think I am all alone for now.
As I wander outside, looking around - left, right, back and forth. I hear a faint flapping of wings. I brace myself, ready to seek shelter in the hut again. As I turn my head slowly, I notice the shadow on the ground in front of me.

Holy smoke! A Dragon! I could have sworn these were only occurring in the folk tales. Stories told to children to keep the from going out at night. But right now, this shadow is roaming around my hut. Look at the size of that thing, it's almost 13 meters long, with a wing span of at least three tall men.
I run back into the hut, panting and sweating at the sight of the fierce creature.
